Award.AwardTitle: Multipoint Observations of Compressional Pulsations: Testing Possible Generation Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ultra-low frequency (3 to 15 minute periods) electromagnetic waves called Pc 5 pulsations have been studied for over 50 years. They are an important magnetospheric phenomenon because they convert energy from one form to another and transmit energy from one location to another. Although there have been a number of physical explanations proposed for these waves their origin remains unknown. This proposal seeks to determine the origin of one class of these waves ? compressional Pc 5 pulsations. The Principal Investigator of this proposal will be assisted by a graduate student in carrying out this research protocol.


These are waves in the Pc 5 frequency range for which there are oscillations along the direction of the background magnetic field. Three mechanisms have been proposed for these waves: drift mirror instabilities due to pressure anisotropies, drift bounce instabilities and injection of blobs of plasma sheet plasma into the inner magnetosphere. The combination of THEMIS observations near the equator and Cluster observations in polar orbit now makes it possible to determine which of these mechanisms are operating.
The following questions have been identified for study:
1. What mechanism generates compressional pulsations in the dawn and dusk magnetosphere?
2. What are the characteristics of the compressional pulsations, including their spatial extent and latitudinal structure?
3. What mechanism generates the subcategory of compressional waves exhibiting frequency doubling (the frequency of the compression component of the waves is twice that of the transverse components) and how do suprathermal particles respond to the pulsations?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Taking advantage of the multipoint   observations of the magnetic field, energetic particle, plasma and the electric field observations we performed comprehensive studies of properties  of  isolated and long-lasting poloidal  Pc4 pulsations  and compressional Pc5  pulsations.  We investigated the spectral structure of the long-lasting Pc4 pulsations and showed that each spacecraft observed a decrease of the dominant period as it moved to a smaller L shell (stronger magnetic field strength) and it was a spatial rather than a temporal effect.  Figure 1 shows densities, total magnetic field strengths and Alfv?n velocities vs. universal time for Van Allen Probes A and B  on four orbits on May 1, 2014. The different Alfven velocities on four orbits  resulted primarily from changes in the plasma density. The density increased from Orbit 1 to Orbit 4 consistent with ionospheric plasma refilling the eroded plasmasphere during the late recovery phase. We tested the hypothesis that the Pc4 pulsations were generated in close proximity to the plasmapause and did not find any direct relationship between the location of plasmapause and the pulsations.  We investigated interactions of ULF pulsations with energetic particles such as wave-particle resonance, modulation and particle acceleration.  We presented multipoint observations concerning the response of the electric and magnetic fields, plasma and energetic particles in the magnetosphere to an interplanetary (IP) shock on February 27, 2014. The shock produced compressional Pc5 magnetic field pulsations observed by GOES 15 in the morning sector of the magnetosphere and a dusk?dawn oscillatory electrical field in the dayside equatorial magnetosphere with a peak-to-peak amplitude of ~ 15 mV m-1 for a period of 30 min. Figures 2 show response of the energetic particles to the transmitted  IP shock.  Van Allen Probes observed enhanced fluxes of energetic electrons in the range of energies from 31.5 to 342   KeV and their intensity shows a regular periodicity, with periods corresponding to the electric field pulsations.   In less than a drift period (panels e and f) in the electrical field of 15 mV/m  electron fluxes increased by factors of 21 and 14 at Van Allen  Probes B and A, respectively. We interpret these observations as evidence for prompt energization of electrons due to shock induced ULF electric fields with an additional contribution for the initial acceleration from the compressional effect of the shock. We used Van Allen Probes and GOES 13-15  multipoint magnetic field, plasma and  energetic particle observations to study the spatial, temporal  and spectral characteristics of compressional   Pc5 pulsations   on  January 1, 2016. Figure 3 presents three components of dynamic spectra of  the magnetic field observations  at Probes A and B from  18:30 to 21:10 UT and from 20:50  UT to 23:10 UT.  The magnetic field dynamic spectra exhibit several broad band enhancements   in the range of frequencies from  ~ 5  mHz to ~ 28 mHz.  The strongest power densities in the spectra occur in the Bz component at frequencies of ~5-6 mHz for both spacecraft as expected for the compressional  Pc5  types of pulsations. Two red arrows in the  Bz component at Probes A  and B indicate an occurrence of the peculiar  pulsations called double frequency pulsations when the compressional component oscillated with a frequency twice as high as that  of the transverse component.  The enhancement of power densities at frequencies of  ~ 25-28 mHz   displayed  mostly in the radial component  can be attributed to poloidal Pc4 pulsations generating simultaneously with the Pc5  pulsations but likely  having a different source of energy. The frequencies of the Pc4 pulsations varied with radial distance. An explanation for this behavior can be given in terms of standing Alfv?n waves along resonant field lines.  By contrast, Fourier analysis of the magnetic field observations   shows   that  the compressional  Pc5 pulsations  exhibited  similar spectra at different radial distances.  The long duration of the Pc5 pulsations and their nearly constant frequencies indicate that the plasma conditions in the morning sector of magnetosphere were stable for more than two hours. We demonstrated that when  the  spacecraft were in the vicinity of  the geomagnetic equator at  local times from 10:00 LT to 12:30 LT  Van Allen Probes and GOES 15 observed meridional sloshing of the   equatorial wave node  confined to the range  of  Zsm   from 0.5 Re to -0.8 Re  and its amplitudes did not exceed  1.3 Re We searched for possible solar wind triggers and discuss generation mechanisms for the compressional Pc5 pulsations  in terms of drift mirror instability and  drift bounce resonance.   We report   the first evidence for the meridional sloshing of the  equatorial node in variations of  electrons fluxes  and  electron density.  The  results of the project  can   provide  some new insights into the global distribution properties  of ULF wave  and  understanding on how populations of relativistic electrons and ions in space form or change in response to changes in solar activity and the solar wind.
